Description: Microsoft Entra interactive and non-interactive sign-ins

Table Data.Description: Date and time when the record was generated
Application that performed the recorded action
Unique identifier for the application
Type of logon session, specifically interactive, remote interactive (RDP), network, batch, and service
Contains the error code if a sign-in error occurs. To find a description of a specific error code, visit https://aka.ms/AADsigninsErrorCodes.
Unique identifier of the sign-in event
Unique number assigned to a user by a website's server for the duration of the visit or session
Name displayed in the address book entry for the account user. This is usually a combination of the given name, middle initial, and surname of the user.
Unique identifier for the account in Microsoft Entra ID
User principal name (UPN) of the account
Indicates if the user that signed in is external. Possible values: -1 (not set), 0 (not external), 1 (external).
Indicates whether the user that signed in is a guest in the tenant
On-premises user principal name (UPN) of the user signing in to Microsoft Entra ID
Date and time when the user that signed in last changed their password
Display name of the resource accessed. The display name can contain any character.
Unique identifier of the resource accessed
Unique identifier of the tenant of the resource accessed
Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the device
Unique identifier for the device in Microsoft Entra ID
Platform of the operating system running on the device. Indicates specific operating systems, including variations within the same family, such as Windows 11, Windows 10, and Windows 7.
Indicates the trust type of the device that signed in. For managed device scenarios only. Possible values are Workplace, AzureAd, and ServerAd.
Indicates whether the device that initiated the sign-in is a managed device (1) or not a managed device (0)
Indicates whether the device that initiated the sign-in is compliant (1) or non-compliant (0)
Details about the authentication processor
Type of authentication required for the sign-in. Possible values: multiFactorAuthentication (MFA was required) and singleFactorAuthentication (no MFA was required).
Indicates if the token issuer is Microsoft Entra ID (0) or Active Directory Federation Services (1)
Aggregated risk level during sign-in. Possible values: 0 (aggregated risk level not set), 1 (none), 10 (low), 50 (medium), or 100 (high).
Details about the risky state of the user that signed in
Indicates risky user state. Possible values: 0 (none), 1 (confirmed safe), 2 (remediated), 3 (dismissed), 4 (at risk), or 5 (confirmed compromised).
User agent information from the web browser or other client application
Indicates the client app used
Details about the version of the browser used to sign in
Details of the conditional access policies applied to the sign-in event
Status of the conditional access policies applied to the sign-in. Possible values are 0 (policies applied), 1 (attempt to apply policies failed), or 2 (policies not applied).
IP address assigned to the device during communication
Two-letter code indicating the country/region where the client IP address is geolocated
State where the sign-in occurred, if available
City where the account user is located
The north to south coordinates of the sign-in location
The east to west coordinates of the sign-in location
Network location details of the authentication processor of the sign-in event
Unique identifier of the request
Unique identifier for the event

IP address assigned to the endpoint and used during related network communications

Description: Sign-ins and other authentication events on devices

Table Data.Description: Date and time when the event was recorded
Unique identifier for the device in the service
Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the device
Type of activity that triggered the event

Type of logon session, specifically: - Interactive - User physically interacts with the device using the local keyboard and screen - Remote interactive (RDP) logons - User interacts with the device remotely using Remote Desktop, Terminal Services, Remote Assistance, or other RDP clients - Network - Session initiated when the device is accessed using PsExec or when shared resources on the device, such as printers and shared folders, are accessed - Batch - Session initiated by scheduled tasks - Service - Session initiated by services as they start

User name of the account
Security Identifier (SID) of the account

Description: Microsoft 365 email events, including email delivery and blocking events

Table Data.Description: Date and time when the event was recorded
Unique identifier for the email, generated by Microsoft 365
Public-facing identifier for the email that is set by the sending email system
Sender email address in the MAIL FROM header, also known as the envelope sender or the Return-Path address
Sender email address in the FROM header, which is visible to email recipients on their email clients

IPv6 address of the last detected mail server that relayed the message
Email address of the recipient, or email address of the recipient after distribution list expansion
Unique identifier for the email recipient in Microsoft Entra ID
Subject of the email
Identifier for the group of similar emails clustered based on heuristic analysis of their contents
Direction of the email relative to your network:  Inbound, Outbound, Intra-org
Delivery action of the email: Delivered, Junked, Blocked, or Replaced
Location where the email was delivered: Inbox/Folder, On-premises/External, Junk, Quarantine, Failed, Dropped, Deleted items
Verdict from the email filtering stack on whether the email contains malware, phishing, or other threats
Detection name for malware or other threats found
Methods used to detect malware, phishing, or other threats found in the email

List of confidence levels of any spam or phishing verdicts. For spam, this column shows the spam confidence level (SCL), indicating if the email was skipped (-1), found to be not spam (0,1), found to be spam with moderate confidence (5,6), or found to be spam with high confidence (9). For phishing, this column displays whether the confidence level is "High" or "Low".
Threshold assigned to email from bulk mailers, a high bulk complaint level (BCL) means the email is more likely to generate complaints, and thus more likely to be spam

Final action taken on the email based on filter verdict, policies, and user actions:  Move message to junk mail folder, Add X-header, Modify subject, Redirect message, Delete message, send to quarantine, No action taken, Bcc message

Action policy that took effect: Antispam high-confidence, Antispam, Antispam bulk mail, Antispam phishing, Anti-phishing domain impersonation, Anti-phishing user impersonation, Anti-phishing spoof, Anti-phishing graph impersonation, Antimalware, Safe Attachments, Enterprise Transport Rules (ETR)
Unique identifier for the policy that determined the final mail action
List of pass or fail verdicts by email authentication protocols like DMARC, DKIM, SPF or a combination of multiple authentication types (CompAuth)
Number of attachments in the email
Number of embedded URLs in the email
Detected language of the email content
Custom instructions that define organizational mail flow and how the email was routed
Action taken on the email in response to matches to a policy defined at the organizational level
Organizational policy that triggered the action taken on the email
Action taken on the email in response to matches to a mailbox policy defined by the recipient
End-user mailbox policy that triggered the action taken on the email
Event identifier based on a repeating counter. To identify unique events, this column must be used in conjunction with the DeviceName and Timestamp columns.
Additional information about the email event

Description: Queries for Active Directory objects, such as users, groups, devices, and domains

Table Data.Description: Date and time when the event was recorded
Type of activity that triggered the event. See the in-portal schema reference for details
Application that performed the recorded action
Type of query, such as QueryGroup, QueryUser, or EnumerateUsers
Name of user, group, device, domain, or any other entity type being queried
String used to run the query
Protocol used during the communication
User name of the account
Domain of the account
User principal name (UPN) of the account
Security Identifier (SID) of the account
Unique identifier for the account in Microsoft Entra ID
Name of the account user displayed in the address book. Typically a combination of a given or first name, a middle initial, and a last name or surname.
Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the device
IP address assigned to the endpoint and used during related network communications
TCP port used during communication
Name of the device running the server application that processed the recorded action
IP address of the device running the server application that processed the recorded action
Destination port of related network communications
Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the device that the recorded action was applied to
User principal name (UPN) of the account that the recorded action was applied to
Display name of the account that the recorded action was applied to
City, country/region, or other geographic location associated with the event
Unique identifier for the event
Additional information about the entity or event

Description: Safe Links clicks from email messages, Teams, and Office 365 apps

Table Data.Description: The date and time when the user clicked on the link
The full URL that was clicked on by the user
Indicates whether the click was allowed or blocked by Safe Links or blocked due to a tenant policy, for instance, from Tenant Allow Block list
User Principal Name of the account that clicked on the link
The application from which the user clicked on the link, with the values being Email, Office, and Teams
The unique identifier for the email that contains the clicked link, generated by Microsoft 365
Verdict at the time of click, which tells whether the URL led to malware, phish or other threats
Detection technology that was used to identify the threat at the time of click
Public IP address of the device from which the user clicked on the link
Indicates whether the user was able to click through to the original URL (1) or not (0)
For scenarios involving redirections, it includes URLs present in the redirection chain
The unique identifier for a click event. For clickthrough scenarios, report ID would have same value, and therefore it should be used to correlate a click event.
